content.content: Delirium is “sudden confusion” that happens over hours or a few days. It can come and go during the day. Delirium is not the forgetfulness of aging or dementia. In some people delirium can be reversed when the cause is known and treated.[^1] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/CHA2Hzg5Kkk ### Risks:[^1] - Dementia - Elderly patients - Antipsychotic drugs - Alcohol, sedatives or pain killers - Withdrawal from alcohol or nicotine - Surgeries - Depression - Infections - Impaired vision or hearing - Brain disorders like stroke or Parkinson’s disease - Dehydration - Constipation or urinating - Chemical or hormone imbalances - ICU admission ### Symptoms:[^1] - Not thinking clearly - Can’t understand what is happening - Seeing or hearing things not there - Fearful that people are going to hurt them - Not paying attention - Easily distracted - Slurred or rambling speech - Not moving or walking as usual - Sleeping changes - Memory losses - Incontinence - Not following directions - Withdrawn and quiet - Acting angry, frightened or ashamed - Difficulty reading and/or writing ### Diagnosis:[^1] - Neurological tests - Cognitive tests - Physical tests - Blood, urine and other diagnostic tests ### Prevention:[^1][^2] - Bring a complete list of prescribed medications, over-the-counter medications, and supplements. - Make a list of all allergies, doctors, pharmacy, and medical conditions. - Ask that necessary medical records be sent to the doctors who will care for the patient. - Bring glasses, hearing aids (with fresh batteries), and dentures. - Bring a few small objects from home. Family photos, a book, a clock, music, and relaxation tapes may be comforting. - Tell the patient where they are, what time it is, and the weather throughout the day. Speak calmly. - Give instructions for one simple task at a time. Don’t overwhelm them. - Avoid arguments - Help the patient walk often when it’s safe per the nurse & doctor. - Stay with the patient as much as you can. During an acute episode of delirium, family should try to be with the patient around the clock. - Speak with the nurse or doctor if new signs that could be delirium (confusion, memory problems, and personality changes) as soon as you can. Families are often the first to notice changes. - How much water or fluids should the patient be drinking? - Wash your hands and the patient’s hands before helping them. - When will the urinary catheter be removed? - Can the patient sleep undisturbed at night?  ### Questions to Ask:[^1] - What is delirium? - What are the symptoms? - How long will it last? - Can it be prevented? - What causes delirium? - Could the medications cause confusion? - Could alcohol withdrawal cause delirium? - What can I do to keep the patient safe? - When can your loved one start walking? - What is being done to prevent infections? - Can non-opioid medications be used for pain? - Will the “ABCDEF bundle” checklist be used?[^3] - Ask if haloperidol or ziprasidone will be given. Both have not been proven as delirium treatments.[^4] __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") ### Treatment:[^1] - Medical evaluation - Adjust medications as needed - Make changes to the patient’s surroundings if needed - Avoid antipsychotic and benzodiazepine medications in calm or non-threatening patients. - Only use antipsychotic medications if behavioral interventions have failed.
